solution_line_template: On Tuesday, Tristan studies twice as long as he did on Monday and this amounts to {monday_study_hours} hours * {tuesday_multiplier} = <<{monday_study_hours}*{tuesday_multiplier}={tuesday_study_hours}>>{tuesday_study_hours} hours.

So in the first 5 days of the week, he studies for a total of {monday_study_hours} hours Monday + {tuesday_study_hours} hours Tuesday + {midweek_daily_hours} hours Wednesday + {midweek_daily_hours} hours Thursday + {midweek_daily_hours} hours Friday = {first_five_days_total} hours.

He therefore has {total_planned_hours} planned hours - {first_five_days_total} used hours = <<{total_planned_hours}-{first_five_days_total}={remaining_study_hours}>>{remaining_study_hours} hours left to study.

As he splits his time evenly over {weekend_days} days, he spends {remaining_study_hours} hours / {weekend_days} = <<{remaining_study_hours}/{weekend_days}={saturday_study_hours}>>{saturday_study_hours} hours studying on Saturday.
